content: I solved this problem by trying all possible cuts with dp, but I still don't understand why greedy algorithm won't work. Could you explain?
Hey quick question here: I solved the problem (all validators pass) but some tests do not pass. Would you have an idea of why?

In general I don't like problem descriptions like this, but this one is so well-done that I actually enjoyed it. At first sight the problem seemed trivial, but it was not the case (not too hard though). If you look at the DP tag, the problem is quite straightforward.

I like the chocolate tag, it is funny.

Nice and simple DP problem (at least in this edge-to-edge splitting version), funny statement (I don't know about the "Chocolate" tag, but whatever ^^). Only 4 testcases, yet they are enough to distinguish from the "general" problem (https://oeis.org/A219158 among others, hence forbidding any hardcoded approach, even though I don't think that's an actual concern).

. o O {"medium"... Dafuq}  
Ah, well, let's see...  

5min later:
"Play all testcases"... <click>
green...
green...
*leans-back*
red!
What?...

some frantic scribbling and thinking later

Ahhhh *facepalm* _that's_ the catch. (still coding for the solution, but got the idea)

---------------   

Very nice. +1  
now i have to wait to watch the stream in fear of spoilers...?

Who forgot to write a stub generator while streaming?
I forgot to write a stub generator while streaming!

There, fixed.

This puzzle is the result of 2019-01-27 streaming session.

https://youtu.be/Nr6ZMphRGLI

Well, the stream does almost start with solving it, so yeah if you intend to solve independently, you're better off postponing that.

Then again, it's public information by now, so I suppose it's fair game to all.

You'll have noticed (as I did in the stream) that OEIS gives neither closed-form nor recurrent formula, so I think we're pretty safe from both ends for now.

Thanks for the comment and approval!

[The general problem was the inspiration for this, but the original author hasn't yet come back. I'll give him a few months before I push through again.]

We're allowed five tags, and I was out of inspiration after one. It's not like they're a limit of any sort :o) I mean, it might reveal itself very helpful if someone comes along who only likes chocolate-themed puzzles, right?

Thanks for the approval!

Nope.

You'd better ask on the forum, you'll get  better response rate.
Could you describe your greedy algorithm?
cutting the biggest possible square from one edge at any instant

I'm not sure there's a simple “reason” why this greedy implementation won't work.  At my level of understanding, all I can provide is an “it doesn't work because you can't prove it to”. (and you can't prove it because it would be wrong)  Smallest counterexample is no larger than 5x6: it is optimal to first split 5 = 3+2.
Oh my.  All my cases work with greedy except for Validators 3 and 4.  Thanks for raising this, I'll fix ASAP.

Wait, false alarm, I had my greedy implementation calling the dp one half of the time.

In addition to t/v 1, the only weird one is validator two, who happens to work with greedy. I think that's fine as is, as none of t/v 3 and 4 do.
Yeah, it's fine. And thanks for the example :)
I really think tags are very well.-chosen. One is funny and one is very helpful, which is needed if someone wants to learn here. And of course, only monsters don't like chocolate. :)

I guess you're referring to some specific candidate CG problem that was washed away when timeouts were introduced. But I didn't know about that, I was more generally referring to the rather famous problem consisting in (perfect- and/or minimal-) squaring the square (or rectangle):
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Squaring_the_square
Yes, that's exactly what the puzzle was (involuntarily) about.
